segments.text: the smart bombs and watching them too?
Yeah, I was watching Channel 9, and they showed about these laser-guided or radio-guided bombs, how they get them to blow up their target.
And, you know, I pieced two and two together.
That's what we did.
We helped conduct their experiments and perfect their laser bombs and stuff.
What do you think of that?
I mean, all those men that got lost when trying to retrieve that bomb, did you think that was the time and place to be doing something like that?
No, no.
But, you know, I figured somebody had to do it.
You know, if it wasn't done there, it might have been done under worse conditions.
Maybe something, maybe the enemy might have got it and ruined whatever plans we had.
for that weapon.
But it was just a part of us being mobile, amphibious, that we could go anywhere.
I think it was harder on us because we not only had to maintain this vehicle weight, 34 tons, that we had to keep going over here.
an infantryman out in the jungle.
All he's got is his rifle and his pack on his back.
Yet we had an extra burden to haul all over Vietnam.
Did you ever have any close buddies that were wounded?
And were you ever wounded?
Yeah, I had a few, quite a few that were wounded.
I was never hurt.
I was lucky.
Just bullets would bounce around me from sniper fire.
But I guess I was really fortunate in that we had one guy that got shot in the throat.
And the way the doctors told us, he could have lived if he hadn't given up.
But he just gave up and died.
And there was a lot of guys that every once in a while we'd have to haul back some dead bodies inside in the body banks.
And that was pretty gross.
But the way I felt that if I ever got shot or if I was going to get killed, I didn't want to see it coming.
Just get caught completely by surprise.
Not even see the man that shot me.
So when y'all ever killed any B.C.
male like that one time in the village, what did you do with those bodies?
I mean, were there any, like, kind of, I've heard stories where, like, taken off the ears or...
I never saw it done.
I never saw it done.
I heard about stuff, but I never saw anybody with ears or body parts or anything, or teeth or anything.
I'm not saying it never happened, because it's been my experience with people that people are capable of anything.
But I never saw it done.
And I wouldn't do it.
I wouldn't be a part of it.
The worst kind of tortures I ever saw were done because we carried the Korean soldiers, too.
Now, they were real cold-blooded torturers.
They would, when they were interrogating Viet Cong prisoners, they would torture them with stick thorns in their ears and then slap them into their ears.
And we were nearby because we had to transport them.
We could hear their screams and everything.
And they'd hang people.
When they were through torturing them, shoot them in the back of the head if they were too...
cut up or emulated.
But it was mainly done by the Koreans.
So y'all just had a policy of what turning the other way until they were done with their business.
Right.
Any of the buddies that you ever had, did you ever feel like maybe they were losing it?
Did you ever feel like, my god, I want to get out of here?
And you just didn't think you could handle another day?
Did you ever see any instances of your fellow peers breaking down?
Yeah, I saw some would break down to the point where they would like cowardice in the face of the enemy, or they didn't want to go on a patrol, or they turned to drugs.
I'd say one third of possible
You know, 100 would go bad and break down.
So are you saying that where did they get drugs and when did they use them?
I mean, when they were out on patrol or what?
Drugs you could get just driving down the road.
The sellers would be standing alongside the road with big packs of marijuana cigarettes like that in their hand.
And we'd be in a convoy, and whenever the convoy would slow down,
Some guys would buy it.
This one guy knew he was buying it and shipping it home.
He was from Chicago.
He was supplying his buddies in Chicago, and they would send him the money to buy it.
And then whenever we went out on patrol or a mission, we would make sure there weren't any dopers in our outfit.
How do you do that?
search them or, you know, you can tell by living with the guys.
Because marijuana, you can smell it.
It smells weird.
I don't know if you've ever smelled it.
No, I smell it too.
And then you could tell the guys are spaced out because they act kind of out of it, you know.
So before we went out on patrol, we knew who was
with it and who was on drugs, and we wouldn't let them go with us.
Or else we'd search them for their stuff and make them leave it behind.
If there was a pot smoker or two, we'd go ahead and take them, but without their marijuana.
Did you ever smoke marijuana?
I mean, did you ever think?
I did try it once, but it made me sick.
It scared me.
It kind of like paralyzed me.
It scared me so bad I never did it again, just that one time.
And it was in a tent.
We had our corpsman.
He was a pot smoker.
He had what was called a pot party.
I didn't want any part of it.
I guess it was just my attitude, my...
deep down personal resentment for it.
It caused me to have a bad reaction to it.
And I felt like I was paralyzed sitting there.
And I thought to myself, oh shit, what am I going to do if a Viet Cong attack now?
Or if they're coming?
I felt so immobilized that an enemy could be holding a gun on me and I couldn't move.
I was just paralyzed.
So I never tried it again.
Never did.
didn't want anything to do with it.
So is that what y'all did on your free time?
I mean, did y'all mainly work at night and then in the day, what did you do?
Yeah, well, we maintained our vehicles and then we had to keep our own living areas clean.
And then we were sent on details to clean different areas at camp.
Our human waste, we had to burn it every day.
And then we had to dig
bunkers.
Whenever we got shelled, we had to hide underground in these bunkers.
And then the command tractors needed extra maintenance because they had four sets of radios, one for aircraft, one for naval gunfire and artillery fire, and then basic headquarters communications.
So
They moved us.

Every once in a while, we had to do a certain amount of time with the headquarters platoon to stay in touch with evacuation procedures, the mobile command headquarters, the operation of the vehicle, and how to stay in tune with command decisions and stuff.
And then we'd rotate to the other platoons

another platoon, the platoon with the best vehicles would be sent the farthest out on the jungle patrols and there was this one operation it was called Operation Snaggle Tooth and it was an ongoing operation the one platoon with the best tractors would always go on that operation and we got to go on it once because
They reassigned us and reformed us into the Marines were going to make one final push on this Operation Snaggletooth.
And off the coast, there was this island that was all Viet Cong held.
And they'd sent the Marines out there to try and wipe them out.
But they were real fierce.
It was a hardcore North Vietnamese army.
And there was a lot of Marines lost before they finally did take that island.
And at night when we were on beach guard, bodies would come floating across the ocean and wash up on the shore.
Some would be North Vietnamese.
And every once in a while, there'd be a Marine in there.
You all would collect them?
Yeah.
Turn them over to wherever.
If it was a Marine, well, we'd turn it over to our graves registration.
And if it was an enemy, we'd turn it over to the... Our intelligence unit would search the bodies.
G2 was intelligence.
They'd come and claim the bodies and search them, try to figure out if he was a real North Vietnamese or a Viet Cong insurgent from the area.
Were your officers ever obsessed with body counts?
Like, that was important?
And did you feel that was a good rate or way to measure things?
Our officers weren't.
It was mainly the infantry outfits that we supported.
Whenever we'd take them supplies, this one company was always going out in the jungle and getting into heavy combat.
They called him Suicide Charlie.
because their officers had suicidal tendencies.
The missions they would send them on, they were always outnumbered and outgunned.
And then there was another company called Dying Delta Company, D Company, because they would get shot up and overrun.
Because of the area, the jungle they were in, the enemy had real eyes.
strength and they would attack them and kill quite a few.
So those were about the worst infantry companies we had ever gotten mixed up with.
Dying Delta and Suicide Charlie.
How were the conditions like?
Do you think you were fed well or maybe compared to other officers?
Yeah, we got to eat a lot better than
Because we would carry the food to the infantry, and every once in a while they'd try to give the infantry a good hot meal.
So they'd send us to this big mess hall in Da Nang, and we'd load up with these insulated canisters of hot food and take it out to the infantry.
Well, and along the way we'd help ourselves.
And...
So we were fortunate in that area.
We got to handle all the supplies, and when you handle all the supplies, you get to pick the best.
So we were fortunate.
But then, too, again, we had to maintain this vehicle.

Every once in a while, when we replaced some of the parts that weighed 100 pounds, like the torsion arms and wheels and the track, so we'd have to use sledgehammers to take the track apart, knock the pins out,
And in the sand, these pins and track would wear out.
So we'd lay the track out and replace all the pins that there was too much play in the track.
Put all new pins in, button it back up, and check our torsion arms and everything, all our suspension system and overhaul in.
So I was pretty muscular and everything from swinging a sledgehammer and maintaining these vehicles.
You said that you went near the DMZ line?
DMZ or DMC?
DMZ, Demilitarized Zone.
So what does that mean?
Is there lots of fighting there?
Well, basically what it was supposed to be is a border between North and South Vietnam, and no military positions or equipment were allowed in this area.
But every once in a while,
nor Vietnamese would sneak people across through there.
It was never honored.
And mainly what we did was, you know, again, river patrols of the rivers that were in that area.
Because a river over there is like a highway here to us.
They use it to transport stuff rather than pack their way through the jungle.
We were like a highway patrol over there.
And any ship that tried to run away from us, we had orders to sink it.
And then we sunk quite a few boats.
After a while, why were you there in the beginning, and why did you think you were there later on?
Did you really think that that was why you were there?
I'm trying to say, and also, did you have any, like, you were really anti-communist, and did you think China was helping the Vietnamese in North Vietnam at all?
Yeah, I grew up with an extreme sense of patriotism because of, you know, my fathers had defended this country, and my grandfather in World War I, my father and uncles in World War II.
When Kennedy...
came out that he was against communism and they tried to attack Cuba and that he supported the operation against Cuba in the Bay of Pigs.
And then Lee Harvey Oswald was his communists affiliation.
He was, you know, spent some time in Russia and he assassinated Kennedy.
Well,
I had a deep sense against communism and the way, you know, Kennedy had tried to stop it.
So I, at first, when I first got to Vietnam, I thought we were doing the right thing and trying to stop communism.
But as the war dragged on and I did my 13 months of where I came home and I saw the politics and everything,
I was sorry, you know, I had ever participated.
Because I knew we weren't going to win, and yet we had already lost thousands of lives and young men's lives.
So I started to just want an end to it.
When did you know you weren't going to win?
I mean, when you went there, obviously you thought we were going to win, right?
Yeah, right, back in the 60s.
In the 60s, it looked good, like we were going...
And then when I came home, Johnson was committing more and more troops.
And then when I finally realized we weren't going to win was when Nixon took over.
And then at the end of Johnson's term, you know, how he had aged.
And after all the troops he'd committed and everything, you could tell the toll on him.
And I said, no, we're not going to follow through and win.
I figured we were just going to pull out.
Did you think it was a war or a military assignment?
No, it was a war.
It was definitely a war.
I know it was called a policing action, but if you ever saw a B-52 airstrike where sections of the jungle jump in the air and trees go flying through the air and
You know it's a war.
It is a war.
What was the worst sight you had ever seen there?
I mean, in Vietnam, what scares you the most about bad memories?
I guess just the mutilated bodies and the damage that bullets do.
I was assigned temporary duty in a prisoner of war camp.
and where they kept these North Vietnamese, the real hardcore troops, locked up.
And most of them, the only way they were captured was if they were shot up.
This one guy had a little bullet hole here in his arm, and his whole elbow was missing.
Another guy had his leg shot off.
And when the doctor would go to look at him, we'd have to wash him and scrub his nub.
clean it up for the doctor to look at.
And then some of the prisoners wouldn't eat.
They'd go on hunger strikes, and they would starve to death right there in the cells.
You could just see them.
As it is, they were thin people, but you could almost see a perfect skeleton and skull when they died from starving themselves to death.
Would you say they had a different view of death than maybe we do?
I mean, why did they do that?
I guess it's their way of protesting their conditions, that they're intolerable to their spirit.
Their will to live diminishes being captive.
And I thought to myself, too, if I ever got captured,
that I wouldn't live very long.
I wouldn't want to live like that.
Like I saw these pilots that were captured by the North, the way they were treated and beaten and dehumanized.
I said to myself, I'll either make them kill me or I'll escape.
And as a last resort, I'd do away with myself.
But it would really have to be the last resort.

and it was basically these living conditions and then like mainly we were put in charge of guarding the the vietnamese but in another stockade there was marine prisoners and army prisoners and every once in a while they would riot and throw try to set this camp on fire
But only the regular MPs, military police, took care of it.
Shut it off.
You're talking about the prisoners?
Yeah, and the other stockade, they had military prisoners, American soldiers that had done stuff, you know, crimes like, you know, rape or something like that.
stealing, insubordination against officers.
And one night they had a riot, and they would set stuff on fire and throw it over in the Vietnamese prisoner of war camp, trying to set it on fire.
And the MPs went in there, and they shot the hardcore, the real hardcore leaders.
And the rest of them, they
kept them in solitary confinement.
This is the captured North Vietnam?
No, these were American soldiers that had committed crimes that were in Vietnam.
Oh, OK.
So they were kept near the prisoners of war?
Yes.
That way, we had machine gun towers around, and we could cover both prisons if they ever tried to escape or something.
What did you think of those that had committed these war crimes, Americans?
Did you think, hey, it's just something that happens in a war like this?
Yeah.
Were they guilty?
Yeah, they lose their sense, their mission, and their dedication and turn to crime.
I thought they deserved everything they got, especially the hardcore ones that were in solitary confinement.
What were some of the worst things that they did?
Well, I guess rape, murder, mutilation, stuff like that.
That was about the worst thing you can do in a war.
And some would deal in the black market and sell the enemy weapons and stuff.
It was a little bit of everything over there.
Did you ever, OK, this is going to sound weird,
R&R, did you ever get that, you know, and what happened and what did you do?

I got in-country R&R at a place that, it got real glamorous and fancy in the 70s and the late 70s, but when they first opened it up, all they had was a movie screen, and it's called China Beach, that movie episode.
But when it first started up, it was just a place on the beach for,
GIs to rest for three days.
It's nothing like a TV episode.
And they had a big mess hall, and they had fresh eggs, ham and eggs, breakfast, stuff like that.
And that was it, just three days in country.
No alcohol, no women there, or nothing?
Well, they had beer.
Beer was $0.10 a can.
But there weren't any women there.
Really?
Okay, when you were in a village or whenever you encountered an enemy, what were the identifying marks for BC?
I mean, how would you know if somebody was?
Well, it was like saying they wore black pajamas, but that wasn't always true.
But you could tell
by the look in somebody's eyes.
Especially the Orientals, some of them can say a lot with their eyes.
They would try to avoid a direct stare by us.
And then we'd check their IDs, because when we went on patrol in the village, that was our main goal, to check that everyone was properly identified and to search for weapons.
But you could pretty much well tell by someone's actions when they were an enemy or not.

And most of the time they would run away when they heard we were coming and hide and possibly set up an ambush for when we were coming back out or take pot shots as snipers when we were far enough away.
When you ever found out, I mean, that they were there,
How were they treated?
I mean, were they like abused right then and there?
If the hardcore infantry got hold of them, yeah, they would get beaten up right away, interrogated, and then they'd get tied up.
There was this one black infantry guy that we were with, his name was, his nickname was Buttplate, because the M14 had him steal
like flapper on the stock of the gun.
And whenever he captured an enemy, he would beat the crap out of them with that steel plate, bust their heads open and everything.
And they nicknamed him Butt Plate Smith, because he was a big old black guy.
And that's why they nicknamed him.
He would always butt plate somebody on the head.
So you think that was a lot of racism or enemy feelings that made him do this, or what?
He had seen a lot of his friends killed by the Viet Cong and he hated all Orientals.
Understand?
He'd even have trouble with the Koreans that were fighting alongside of him.
Yeah, basically it was like reverse prejudice that he was taking out.
How would you compare the Koreans to Arvin?
The Koreans were the fiercest fighters.
They were always ready to do hand-to-hand combat, always practicing, even on each other.
Early in the morning before breakfast, they'd do martial arts.
And they were real fierce fighters.
Like I told you earlier, they would torture anybody, men, women, old people.
They didn't care.
Torture them and mutilate them.
Did you ever experience any racism there?
Yeah, a couple of times.
Like what?
Well, I was one of the few, there was only about three of us Hispanics in the company I was in.
And some of the harder core white guys were, you could tell they were prejudiced.
They'd make remarks, they called us greasers.
But most of them accepted us.
What surprised me was some of them from Tennessee, because they were real hardcore, prejudiced people in those days, were from North Carolina, Tennessee, Georgia, Alabama, Mobile.
But once you got out in the...
This was, you know, the worst thing to be is in Garrison or in the company area.
Because the guys get on each other's nerves.
You go to the club and drink, and then your basic prejudices come out.
You start taking your nerves out on each other.
But most of the time, this is another reason why I didn't need any R&Rs.
We were always on the move in our vehicles, amphibs, constantly patrolling, always on the move.
Then some, this one infantry area we were in, the black guys, were real prejudice against any kind of Hispanics or white people.
And they had their own group.
It was a bunch of black infantry guys.
And they had set up a boxing ring.
And they would challenge the white guys and anybody they could to get in that ring room.
Did you ever do that?
No, I came close to it.
But...
I'd just tell him, hey, go out there and get Charlie and beat the shit out of him for taking your prejudice out on us, you know?
Do you think that was really strange?
I mean, when you all are supposed to be fighting together and then this racist guy... Yeah, yeah, but like I said, people are capable of anything.
You'd be surprised what you find people doing.
When you found out...
When you had to go home, how did you feel?
I mean, how were you?
Well, I felt happy and nervous and like they were probably going to extend all of us to stay over there or some way to shaft us, well, me.
And you were constantly on guard waiting to get shot or something.
I was lucky I never did get hurt over there.
But you get all kinds of mixed feelings.
You're worried about the long flight home, something's going to go wrong with a plane.
Just a thousand things go through your head.
Did it never happen in your mind that, hey, I want to stay for another tour, come back for another tour or anything like that?
No, not after what I'd seen.
And...
I just had my fill of the war.
And then the politics involved, too.

And then, you know, watching guys go crazy, especially when we came home and we didn't know what was happening to some of the guys, what they were going through, post-traumatic shock syndrome or whatever it's called.
I saw a lot of guys go bananas there at Camp Pendleton.
This one guy, I happened to be the duty NCO that night, and he just came to the front of the building and just started breaking all the windows with his bare hands.
And he was all cut up and bleeding.
That was when you returned home?
Yeah.
I guess that something just snapped in his head.
He was all cut up and bleeding, and I had to call the...
I was in charge of the banks, and I had to call the medical people out there to come help him before he bled to death.

And then another guy borrowed this other guy's car, and when he was driving off the base, he just ran right through the gate real fast, and the MPs fired at him and chased him into town, and ended up...
He was lucky they didn't kill him.
They just wounded him and arrested him.
But a lot of guys that went bananas.
Is there anything, do you feel like you changed in any way?
Yeah, I just have a real serious attitude.
It's hard for me to laugh and ease up.
And mainly I'm just devoted to my job.
When you came home, I always hear stories about, oh, they always gave ticket, whatever, whatever, parades for the other world, for the other wars, and for Vietnam, they didn't care.
Is that the impression you got from the other people here in the United States?
Yeah, well, I try to figure things out for myself.
And, you know, like World War II had a definite end, and...
all the troops were coming home, to me, there never will be a definite end to Vietnam.
Because the way I see it, sooner or later, we're going to have to go back there.
Why?
Different things, like the Orientals, to me, like remember what happened with Japan now?
You know, when we dropped the bomb on them, we thought we had destroyed them.
completely annihilated them.
Now they've started like an economic war.
They're out selling us and they're better off than we are now.
Eventually I think this will lead to an overall clash between the United States and Japan.
To me, as long as there's different races, there's going to be conflicts like
what's going on in South America.
It's a jungle terrain like Vietnam was.
So we have to send troops in there.
I've heard some remarks that those guerrillas in South America say this will be a worse war than Vietnam.
So there'll always be another Vietnam, or it'll never end.
Did anybody ever make you feel ashamed that you had been in Vietnam?
No.
No, I never got the kind of...
Some guys said they got spat on and remarks called baby killers and all that, but I never did.
And even if they did say that to my face, it wouldn't hurt me because I know what kind of service I did over there.
And like I said, I think I did 50% to help the people and the other 50% to hurt the enemy.
So I have a great sense of accomplishment in my service in Vietnam.
What did you think about anti-war protests, burning up the draft cards?
Well, I believe in freedom of speech, and that's another thing I went into the military to defend.
People have a right to express their opinions
Whatever way, shape, or form, it doesn't hurt someone else.
So, it doesn't bother me.
Why do you think we lost FINA?
Because the politicians were afraid that if we invaded the North, it would escalate into war with China and Russia.
I think our politicians were basically afraid they would start World War III.
and it would be against the yellow man.
That's the main thing I think our president, our politicians were afraid of.
Now they have all these Vietnam memorials and whatnot.
What do you think of those things?
I think it's good, but most of it,

doesn't really to me come from the people because like the Vietnam memorial here in San Antonio it's paid being paid for by the veterans themselves so to me these memorials have a hollow empty thing about them and then the the main Vietnam memorial um
Again, you know, I think it's great for the guys that died and, you know, their names are on it, but my name isn't on it.
And it'll, you know, it'll never be on there.
But I think it's great, like I said, for the dead to remember them.
Each individual with his name on that wall.
But it doesn't...
really affect me.
Vietnam, is that something you really want people to know about?
Because I know in grade school and high school, I never learned anything about it.
I'm just really learning about it now.
I think the only way I deal with the stress I feel from having been over there is to educate myself about it, exactly what happened.
And every once in a while, I'll
I'll rent a videotape about the 10,000 Day War.

That's a series of videotapes that tells you exactly why, what happened, what decisions our president made, and how Ho Chi Minh met with his leaders and turned around and overturned the plans of the United States so that he could free his people
would unite, you know, because it was basically a civil war like our civil war, the north against the south.
The south didn't want to go along with the north, so the north started sending troops to kill or overthrow the regime and bring the people back under its control.
So I felt
like we were meddling in affairs that weren't any of our business.
But like I said, I had a tremendous sense to try and stop communism.
I grew up worshiping President Kennedy.
And when someone affiliated with a communist party killed him, I kind of had a bitter pill against communism.
How about Nixon in Cambodia?
Well, I think he did what his military advisors told him.
You know, hey, we're taking a beating.
These guys are running a couple of miles into Cambodia and laughing at us.
It's back to the old cat and mouse routine.
Nixon turned loose the troops to go and do away with that harassment they were getting.
So that was justified?
I think it was, yeah.
I'm going to wind down.
Just how have your feelings changed over time about the war?
Well, like I was saying earlier,
I've studied it and the decisions that were made and it was the politicians that blew it.
And I don't feel bad about it.
It doesn't bother me.
That's how I've overcome my stress and stuff.
I know exactly what happened.
I've educated myself to know what happened and who made what decisions and what brought them to that point.
What do you think about these movies like Platoon and, you know, Apocalypse Now?
Do you think that they really give an accurate portrayal or they're glossing it over?
I don't think Apocalypse Now, I think that more is a comedy, you know, like a satire.
To me, that's what... Platoon, I think it was real accurate as to what happened to the army over there.
It was a pretty good movie to show the young man what war was like in that era, in that time.
But man is always improving and changing his weapons and his tactics, so I think the next war will be even more deadly.
because we're getting to the point where most of our weapons are push-button and there's nothing personal involved, you know.
It's real, more like computer games.
I think that these movies show what war was like then, but for everyone, future generations, it's going to be different.
I'm done asking questions.
If you have any comments that you want to make sure that maybe I understand, that's fine.
If not, that's okay.
No, I just, you know, I had, you asked me earlier if I did want to go back to Vietnam.
You know, when I, like I said, I was over there in the early 60s and it was kind of crude at first.
I think in the
If I had gone back again in the 70s, because I came back in 67, all you had to do was spend 90 days here in the United States, and then the Marines usually would send you back for a second tour.
And I just decided that I'd had enough, and I wasn't going to stay in the Marines because 90 days later I'd end up back in Vietnam.
Because I had a critical MOS, armored personnel carriers were critical MOS.
And I knew I'd end up right back again if I reenlisted, so I got out.
That's about all I have to say.
Okay, thanks.
